People who are not far-right supporters, but part of this protest, may end up joining the cause out of anger, we want to avoid that outcome. I hope the government is cautious in their use of this power. 7/7

They need to feel like they’re part of our society, and that we value them, even if we don’t agree with them. Closing/freezing bank accounts doesn’t do that, if anything it will only serve to further entrench their beliefs, and that’s dangerous. 6/7

I think at this point the people who are found not to have affiliations with the far-right will have to be treated like cult-members. We have to treat them carefully and show empathy, they joined a cause because they’ve been feeling unheard and invalidated. 5/7

I want to see protestors gone. I’m uncomfortable with what they stand for, and who they’ve affiliated themselves with. As I said in a previous post I think they’ve been manipulated by charismatic leaders tailoring messages and misinformation directly to them. 4/7

Freezing people’s accounts is trickier. It has far reaching impacts on individual’s lives, families, ability to shelter, care for children etc. It involves collateral damage (thinking children/family’s especially here). I have very mixed feelings about actions of that nature. 3/7

Business shouldn’t be involved in politics, and certainly shouldn’t be financially involved in protests of any kind. I think when you allow business to engage in activities like that it can quickly become a slippery slope to where they exert influence over our government. 2/7

I’ve spent quite a bit of time this morning considering the implications of freezing and/or closing personal accounts of people involved what is now an illegal occupation. I have no problem with government ordering business accounts to be closed/frozen. 1/7
